intro: Quercus robur var. typica, commonly known as the English oak, is a deciduous tree native to Europe. It is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn golden in autumn. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife. It typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters with a broad, spreading canopy. The bark is thick and fissured, providing a rugged appearance and offering habitat for numerous insects and lichens.
